name: Nori Aoki
best: He gets on base often – around his career percentage of .353 – while hitting in the leadoff position, and he steals about 20 bases and plays good defense.
worst: Aoki, who has virtually no power, is left stranded on base far too often because the guys who do have power are unable to bring him home on a consistent basis.
prediction: He has been remarkably consistent in his four years as a major-leaguer, with batting averages between .285 and .288 and on-base percentages between .349 and .356. So expect more of the same.

name: Ketel Marte
best: He improves on the decent offensive numbers he put up for a half-season as a rookie last year, and the Mariners finally have a shortstop they can count on for years to come.
worst: He regresses offensively in his second season, just like other Mariners middle-infield prospects over the past few years (Dustin Ackley, Nick Franklin and Brad Miller), and struggles at the plate affect his defense.
prediction: With such a small sample size from last year, it’s tough to predict. But here’s guessing he will hit about .250 with 15 stolen bases, which will be enough to keep his job provided he plays good defense.

name: Robinson Cano
best: Last season’s regression was not a sign that age is taking a toll, and he bounces back to hit about .320 with 20 homers and 100 RBI, which would return him among the best second basemen in the major leagues.
worst: His offensive numbers continue to decline, the baserunning blunders from last year return, and that 10-year, $240 million deal he signed looks to be just another disaster from GM Jack Zduriencik’s tenure.
prediction: A season about as good as last year. At 33, he certainly should have a few good years left, but it’s likely he will never be as productive as he was during his best years with the Yankees.

name: Nelson Cruz
best: During a 2015 Mariners season in which few things went as expected, Cruz was the huge exception. If he can deliver another season of 40 or more homers and a batting average even close to last year’s .302, the Mariners would be ecstatic.
worst: The inevitable drop-off (he turns 36 in in July) begins, and the power numbers take a big plunge, along with his batting average.
prediction: He will have a good season, with about 30 homers, a .270 batting average and 90 RBI. Anything more would be remarkable for a player who has had his best season in his mid-30s.

name: Kyle Seager
best: His struggles with runners in scoring position vanish, and he comes much closer to the 96 RBI he had in 2014 than the 74 he had last season, all while playing excellent defense.
worst: The prolonged slumps he has been prone to throughout his career continue. He struggles again to deliver in the clutch after hitting .179 in 145 at-bats with runners in scoring position last season.
prediction: Another solid season  with good power numbers, but a couple of slumps keep his average around .265.

name: Adam Lind
best: He solves the Mariners’ longtime woes at first base, hitting for decent power with a solid batting average. He may never approach the production of 2009 when he had 35 homers, 114 RBI and a .305 average, but a season like last year would be a big improvement for the Mariners.
worst: He regresses from last season and struggles to hit for power, just as he did with Toronto in 2014 (six homers and 40 RBI in 290 at-bats), his most recent season in the AL.
prediction: He will bat about .270 with 20 homers and 75 RBI while hitting almost solely against right-handers – more than the Mariners are used to getting from their first basemen.

name: Seth Smith
best: Something similar to last year, when he was solid against right-handed pitchers (.255 average and .801 OPS, or on-base plus slugging percentage), and he is a big part of a productive outfield platoon with Franklin Gutierrez.
worst: The struggles he had at the end of last season, when he hit .216 from August until the end of the season, were a sign of things to come.
prediction: He has been fairly consistent throughout his career, so expect him to hit about .250 with 12 home runs. That would be enough to keep him in the platoon role.

name: Chris Iannetta
best: Last year’s poor performance was an aberration, and he hits about .250 with 10 to 15 homers.
worst: The big offensive regression last season was not a fluke and, for the second consecutive season, the Mariners have a starting catcher who is unable to hit above .200. If that happens, Mike Zunino’s return could come quicker than anticipated.
prediction: Even at hitter-friendly Coors Field in Denver, Iannetta was never much of a hitter, but he should rebound some and hit about .220 with 10 home runs.

name: Leonys Martin
best: He has a big rebound offensively (he struggled so badly with Texas last year he lost his starting job), hitting about .275 with at least 30 stolen bases and playing some of the best center field in the major leagues.
worst: Another offensive season like he had last year, when he had a horrible .576 OPS for an outfielder and struck out at an alarming rate for a player with little power.
prediction: He will be a liability on offense, hitting about .250 with a low on-base percentage, but his defense will be excellent.

name: Felix Hernandez
best: He at least matches last year’s total of 18 wins, and his ERA and WHIP (walks plus hits per inning pitched) return to Felix-like numbers. That’s what the Mariners have come to expect from Hernandez, who also has been remarkably healthy throughout his career.
worst: The regression last season was not a fluke (his ERA of 3.53 and WHIP of 1.180 were his highest since 2011) as the 2,262 career innings begin to take a toll.
prediction: Last year was the best of his career, and it seems unlikely he could be that good again. But look for 15 to 18 wins and an ERA under 3.00.
